trans-unit.source: Web app with table storage (Node.js) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Web app with table storage (Node.js) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that builds on the Web App with Express tutorial by adding Azure Storage services and the Azure module.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that builds on the Web App with Express tutorial by adding Azure Storage services and the Azure module.

trans-unit.source: Node.js Web Application using Storage
trans-unit.target: Node.js Web Application using Storage

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will extend the application created in the
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will extend the application created in the

trans-unit.source: [Node.js Web Application using Express] tutorial by using the Microsoft
trans-unit.target: [Node.js Web Application using Express] tutorial by using the Microsoft

trans-unit.source: Azure Client Libraries for Node.js to work with data management services.
trans-unit.target: Azure Client Libraries for Node.js to work with data management services.

trans-unit.source: You
trans-unit.target: You

trans-unit.source: will extend your application to create a web-based task-list application
trans-unit.target: will extend your application to create a web-based task-list application

trans-unit.source: that you can deploy to Azure.
trans-unit.target: that you can deploy to Azure.

trans-unit.source: The task list allows a user to
trans-unit.target: The task list allows a user to

trans-unit.source: retrieve tasks, add new tasks, and mark tasks as completed.
trans-unit.target: retrieve tasks, add new tasks, and mark tasks as completed.

trans-unit.source: The task items are stored in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: The task items are stored in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: Storage provides unstructured data storage that is fault-tolerant and
trans-unit.target: Storage provides unstructured data storage that is fault-tolerant and

trans-unit.source: highly available.
trans-unit.target: highly available.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage includes several data structures
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage includes several data structures

trans-unit.source: where you can store and access data, and you can leverage the storage
trans-unit.target: where you can store and access data, and you can leverage the storage

trans-unit.source: services from the APIs included in the Azure SDK for Node.js or
trans-unit.target: services from the APIs included in the Azure SDK for Node.js or

trans-unit.source: via REST APIs.
trans-unit.target: via REST APIs.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Storing and Accessing Data in Azure].
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Storing and Accessing Data in Azure].

trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes that you have completed the [Node.js Web

trans-unit.source: Setting Storage Credentials in Web.Config
trans-unit.target: Setting Storage Credentials in Web.Config

trans-unit.source: To access Azure Storage, you need to pass in storage
trans-unit.target: To access Azure Storage, you need to pass in storage

trans-unit.source: credentials.
trans-unit.target: credentials.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you utilize web.config application settings.
trans-unit.target: To do this, you utilize web.config application settings.

trans-unit.source: Those settings will be passed as environment variables to Node, which
trans-unit.target: Those settings will be passed as environment variables to Node, which

trans-unit.source: are then read by the Azure SDK.
trans-unit.target: are then read by the Azure SDK.

trans-unit.source: Storage credentials are only used when the application is
trans-unit.target: Storage credentials are only used when the application is

trans-unit.source: deployed to Azure.
trans-unit.target: deployed to Azure.

trans-unit.source: When running in the emulator, the application
trans-unit.target: When running in the emulator, the application

trans-unit.source: will use the storage emulator.
trans-unit.target: will use the storage emulator.

trans-unit.source: Perform the following steps to retrieve the storage account credentials
trans-unit.target: Perform the following steps to retrieve the storage account credentials

trans-unit.source: and add them to the web.config settings:
trans-unit.target: and add them to the web.config settings:

trans-unit.source: If it is not already open, start the Azure PowerShell from the Start menu by expanding All Programs, Azure, right-click Azure PowerShell, and then select Run As Administrator.
trans-unit.target: If it is not already open, start the Azure PowerShell from the Start menu by expanding All Programs, Azure, right-click Azure PowerShell, and then select Run As Administrator.

trans-unit.source: Change directories to the folder containing your application.
trans-unit.target: Change directories to the folder containing your application.

trans-unit.source: For example, C:\\node\\tasklist\\WebRole1.
trans-unit.target: For example, C:\\node\\tasklist\\WebRole1.

trans-unit.source: From the Azure Powershell window enter the following cmdlet to retrieve the storage account information:
trans-unit.target: From the Azure Powershell window enter the following cmdlet to retrieve the storage account information:

trans-unit.source: This retrieves the list of storage accounts and account keys associated with your hosted service.
trans-unit.target: This retrieves the list of storage accounts and account keys associated with your hosted service.

trans-unit.source: Since the Azure SDK creates a storage account when you deploy a service, a storage account should already exist from deploying your application in the previous guides.
trans-unit.target: Since the Azure SDK creates a storage account when you deploy a service, a storage account should already exist from deploying your application in the previous guides.

trans-unit.source: Open the ServiceDefinition.csdef file containing the environment settings that are used when the application is deployed to Azure:
trans-unit.target: Open the ServiceDefinition.csdef file containing the environment settings that are used when the application is deployed to Azure:

trans-unit.source: Insert the following block under Environment element, substituting {STORAGE ACCOUNT} and {STORAGE ACCESS KEY} with the account name and the primary key for the storage account you want to use for deployment:
trans-unit.target: Insert the following block under Environment element, substituting {STORAGE ACCOUNT} and {STORAGE ACCESS KEY} with the account name and the primary key for the storage account you want to use for deployment:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>The web.cloud.config file contents</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save the file and close notepad.
trans-unit.target: Save the file and close notepad.

trans-unit.source: Using the Table service in a node application
trans-unit.target: Using the Table service in a node application

trans-unit.source: In this section you will extend the basic application created by the express command by adding a task.js file which contains the model for your tasks.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will extend the basic application created by the express command by adding a task.js file which contains the model for your tasks.

trans-unit.source: You will also modify the existing app.js and create a new tasklist.js file that uses the model.
trans-unit.target: You will also modify the existing app.js and create a new tasklist.js file that uses the model.

trans-unit.source: Create the model
trans-unit.target: Create the model

trans-unit.source: In the WebRole1 directory, create a new directory named models.
trans-unit.target: In the WebRole1 directory, create a new directory named models.

trans-unit.source: In the models directory, create a new file named task.js.
trans-unit.target: In the models directory, create a new file named task.js.

trans-unit.source: This file will contain the model for the tasks created by your application.
trans-unit.target: This file will contain the model for the tasks created by your application.

trans-unit.source: At the beginning of the task.js file, add the following code to reference required libraries:
trans-unit.target: At the beginning of the task.js file, add the following code to reference required libraries:

trans-unit.source: Next, you will add code to define and export the Task object.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will add code to define and export the Task object.

trans-unit.source: This object is responsible for connecting to the table.
trans-unit.target: This object is responsible for connecting to the table.

trans-unit.source: Next, add the following code to define additional methods on the Task object, which allow interactions with data stored in the table:
trans-unit.target: Next, add the following code to define additional methods on the Task object, which allow interactions with data stored in the table:

trans-unit.source: Save and close the task.js file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close the task.js file.

trans-unit.source: Modify the index view
trans-unit.target: Modify the index view

trans-unit.source: Change directories to the views directory and open the index.jade file in a text editor.
trans-unit.target: Change directories to the views directory and open the index.jade file in a text editor.

trans-unit.source: Replace the contents of the index.jade file with the code below.
trans-unit.target: Replace the contents of the index.jade file with the code below.

trans-unit.source: This defines the view for displaying existing tasks, as well as a form for adding new tasks and marking existing ones as completed.
trans-unit.target: This defines the view for displaying existing tasks, as well as a form for adding new tasks and marking existing ones as completed.

trans-unit.source: Save and close index.jade file.
trans-unit.target: Save and close index.jade file.

trans-unit.source: Modify the global layout
trans-unit.target: Modify the global layout

trans-unit.source: The layout.jade file in the views directory is used as a global template for other .jade files.
trans-unit.target: The layout.jade file in the views directory is used as a global template for other .jade files.

trans-unit.source: In this step you will modify it to use <link><linkText>Twitter Bootstrap</linkText><title></title></link>, which is a toolkit that makes it easy to design a nice looking website.
trans-unit.target: In this step you will modify it to use <link><linkText>Twitter Bootstrap</linkText><title></title></link>, which is a toolkit that makes it easy to design a nice looking website.

trans-unit.source: Download and extract the files for <link><linkText>Twitter Bootstrap</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Download and extract the files for <link><linkText>Twitter Bootstrap</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Copy the bootstrap.min.css file from the bootstrap\\dist\\css folder to the public\\stylesheets directory of your tasklist application.
trans-unit.target: Copy the bootstrap.min.css file from the bootstrap\\dist\\css folder to the public\\stylesheets directory of your tasklist application.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to start the application in the emulator.
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to start the application in the emulator.

trans-unit.source: The browser will open and displays the following page:
trans-unit.target: The browser will open and displays the following page:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>A web paged titled My Task List with a table containing tasks and fields to add a new task.</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>A web paged titled My Task List with a table containing tasks and fields to add a new task.</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Use the form to add items, or remove existing items by marking them as completed.
trans-unit.target: Use the form to add items, or remove existing items by marking them as completed.

trans-unit.source: Publishing the Application to Azure
trans-unit.target: Publishing the Application to Azure

trans-unit.source: In the Windows PowerShell window, call the following cmdlet to redeploy your hosted service to Azure.
trans-unit.target: In the Windows PowerShell window, call the following cmdlet to redeploy your hosted service to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Replace myuniquename with a unique name for this application.
trans-unit.target: Replace myuniquename with a unique name for this application.

trans-unit.source: Replace datacentername with the name of an Azure data center, such as West US.
trans-unit.target: Replace datacentername with the name of an Azure data center, such as West US.

trans-unit.source: After the deployment is complete, you should see a response similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: After the deployment is complete, you should see a response similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: As before, because you specified the -launch option, the browser opens and displays your application running in Azure when publishing is completed.
trans-unit.target: As before, because you specified the -launch option, the browser opens and displays your application running in Azure when publishing is completed.

trans-unit.source: Stopping and Deleting Your Application
trans-unit.target: Stopping and Deleting Your Application

trans-unit.source: After deploying your application, you may want to disable it so you can
trans-unit.target: After deploying your application, you may want to disable it so you can

trans-unit.source: avoid costs or build and deploy other applications within the free trial
trans-unit.target: avoid costs or build and deploy other applications within the free trial

trans-unit.source: time period.
trans-unit.target: time period.

trans-unit.source: Azure bills web role instances per hour of server time consumed.
trans-unit.target: Azure bills web role instances per hour of server time consumed.

trans-unit.source: Server time is consumed once your application is deployed, even if the
trans-unit.target: Server time is consumed once your application is deployed, even if the

trans-unit.source: instances are not running and are in the stopped state.
trans-unit.target: instances are not running and are in the stopped state.

trans-unit.source: The following steps show you how to stop and delete your application.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show you how to stop and delete your application.

trans-unit.source: In the Windows PowerShell window, stop the service deployment
trans-unit.target: In the Windows PowerShell window, stop the service deployment

trans-unit.source: created in the previous section with the following cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: created in the previous section with the following cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: Stopping the service may take several minutes.
trans-unit.target: Stopping the service may take several minutes.

trans-unit.source: When the service is stopped, you receive a message indicating that it has stopped.
trans-unit.target: When the service is stopped, you receive a message indicating that it has stopped.

trans-unit.source: To delete the service, call the following cmdlet:
trans-unit.target: To delete the service, call the following cmdlet:

trans-unit.source: When prompted, enter Y to delete the service.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, enter Y to delete the service.

trans-unit.source: Deleting the service may take several minutes.
trans-unit.target: Deleting the service may take several minutes.

trans-unit.source: After the service has been deleted you receive a message indicating that the service was deleted.
trans-unit.target: After the service has been deleted you receive a message indicating that the service was deleted.
